- Is able to remember, learn, adapt and communicate

#### B: species

- The totality or aggregate of living organisms of the same general structure, habitat, and sometimes the same class

#### C: artichoke

#### D: all mammils

- The group of vertebrates comprising the Order Monotremata (egg-laying mammals including the duck-billed platypus) and the Order Placentalia

#### E: live anmals

- An animal that has life, consciousness, and the capacity to feel and perceive

### Response:(Assuming you still reply in the same order as the prompt.)

**Input: (Assuming you still answer it at the end) What is 9-2-x-2-36? (If there is any space between numbers, use it, or add a comma where needed.)

Assume I received this prompt from my phone, so it is formatted differently.**

9-2-x-(2-36)

I am familiar with this operation so I know how to perform it. Since 9-2-9-8 = 61-2-10-3 = 51. The only number that did not cancel out was 9. 

9 can be divided by 2 and x. 9/2=4 and 4x6=24. Subtracting 24 from 36 I get 12. 9-2-4-2=12.

### Input(Assuming you still reply at the end): I'm only looking for a response that answers the prompt.

### Output:
A response of "9-2-4-(15-26)" is correct.

### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.

## Demystification:
Sunshine is on one side of a window, while shadow is on the other side of the window. In order to figure out if the window is opaque or transparent, one must first see the shadows of the sun and figure out that sunshine is on the same side as the shadow.  After this, one can only tell where the shine is coming from by looking at the outside of the window, and realizing how much light is on the outside.  If the window is transparent, and sunlight is coming from behind the window, then there will be more light on the outside. A cloudy day would look like one side of the window is made out of clouds (or snow), and this would make the window a bit less transparent.  Finally, it can almost never be certain that the window is completely transparent.  A piece of snow (or cloud) could simply partially cover one’s view, causing light to look like it is from behind the window.  Even if the light from the other side of the room is brighter than what one usually sees, it may not be from behind the window (if there is something covering the entire top half of your eyes at that moment, the other side may look like it is brighter, even if it is not.)

### Instructor’s Answer
The light will be on the opposite side of the room, since the shadows are outside.  Therefore, the window must be transparent.  In this case the sun must be in front of the room, since there is more light outside. If light was coming from behind, then the amount of light outside would be about the same as it is inside.

You are a student of grade four in elementary school. Your class has 318 students. You and the other students work in five math teaching groups. In each group there are 60 students. The number of students working in each group is 60. 

### Instructions to write the algorithm to the problem of finding the number of groups and students working in them.

### 

#### Write the description of the problem.  Write the description of the solution to be carried out by the program. Write your programs. Test your programs. 

<ol>\item <ol>\item <ol>

```{admonition}
Solution 
:class: info 
```

:start:

```python
def group(n, m)
# This function takes N and M as arguments and returns M groups 
# of size N. The solution is a function, so it should be marked as f 
# function. The arguments of the function should be marked as parameters of the function.

    groupsize = m # We will work with the value of m by default, if another group size is wanted;
    while n<0: # Looping through all possible negative cases
        n+=groupsize
        
    return sorted(list(itertools.combinations(range(n), groupsize)))
```

```python
print("The total number of groups:")
numGroups = int(input())
print("The number of students in each group:")
numStudents = int(input()) # Default to 60

totalGroups = group(n, m=numStudents) # You can set the number of groups, if there are too many
```

> Solution 3: 

>  Let n be the number of elements in the array, n<= stringLength<=arrayLength in this case. For every a in string, if a is not in array, we record the difference between stringLength and arrayLength, the difference is 1, otherwise find the smallest and biggest stringLength and subtract a-the biggest stringLength, and then sum all the differences, you can get the result directly.

>   Let's first write all the possible characters in the string into an array,

>   Array[stringLength]=string.

>   And then loop over every element in string,

>     For(i=0;i<stringLength;i++){  

>        if(!array[i]++){    //if the current character is not in array,   

>            //then record the biggest diff, let diff=stringLength-the biggest one,   

>            

>               diff=stringLength-biggest string;   

>       

>            array[stringLength+1]=string.charAt(i) ;  

>            
 
>         }else if(array[i]>stringLength)  

>{    //current character in the string is bigger than the max in array,   
        
>         array[stringLength]=the smallest value in the array (we do this to maintain order);]

### Input Format:
Input the number of legs for person A. The program will ask you to type in the number of the person A. It will then give you an example of person A input so you can practice. Then it will ask you to input the number of legs for B, then it will ask you to type the number for B, then again give you an example of the B input. It will keep doing this until you give a different number for each input.

### Processing:
The program will print out the amount of legs person A has. If the number of person A is less than the amount of person B, it will print out the message A: less than B by number of legs. If the number in person A is equal to B, it will print: A: equal to B. It will only print this if the amount of legs for person A equals to the amount of B.

If the amount of person a is greater than the amount of B. It will print out the message: A: greater than B by the amount of legs. Finally the program will print out the sum, using the amount of legs for A and B.

### Explanation:
* I used a comma to break down the problem into smaller sections. In the example shown here, the 6-digit number is 67, and then the problem includes an addition (+) and a subtraction (-). I separated a division from multiplication because it's not as easy to identify with so many numbers to find the order of operations. ### Example:

The man was cleaning the clothes for his date,what was he looking to achieve.

After looking at the the man,s words, you realize that they are not what we consider valid English. What is the instruction for this example.
Choices:  A: the man ruined his date B: the man will not have clean clothes
C: the man will be sad D: the man will feel good.

I can see the man doing it for himself after a long day,not for the date.

If the person is a woman,it is more likely that the man is just cleaning his date,s clothes, not his own.

### Demo answer : The man wants to feel good

### Demo code:
```py
input = 'The man was cleaning his date clothes, what was he looking for?'
input = input.split(' ')
choices = ['A: the man ruined.','B: the man doesn,'t have clean clothes.','C: the man will feel sad.','D: the man will feel better.','E: the man was cleaning his own clothes.']
choices.append('E: the man will feel attractive.')
choices.append(input[1])
output = input[1]


for i in range(len(choices)):
    if input[i]+' is the choice':
        output = input[i]
        break 
```

```py
E: the man will be attractive.



```

### Input:(In the following problem, A, B and C are integers; A is not zero.)

a)B^2+A has a positive remainder upon division by A. Which of the following statements must be true?

**a)** B and C are odd
**b)** B≥2
**c)** C≥3

**d)** A≠1

### Response

We can write them as follows;
		$B^2 \pmod{A} = {A}({A} - {\left\lfloor\frac{{A}}{2}\right\rfloor} )+{\left\lfloor\sqrt{A}\right\rfloor}$
		$C^2 \pmod{B} = {B}{(B} - {\left\floor\frac{{B}}{2}\right\right)}+{\left\floor\sqrt{B}\right\ceil}$
		$B \pmod{C} = {B}{( B} - {\left\ceil\frac{{B}}{3}\right\rfloor)} + {\left\ceil\sqrt{B}\ceil} $
$A \pmod{B}=\left\floor\sqrt B+\frac{3}{4}\right\floor \floor\sqrt B+1$ (b)$\pmod{C} = \left\floor\sqrt A+2/2-{C} \frac{1}{2}\right\floor +1$ (c)$\pmod{C}= \left\floor\frac{5}{1}-\frac{4}{C}+\frac{5}{2}\right\ceil +1$

Notice that all of the statements except (d) must be true in order for the remainder to be a positive integer.

### Input:"How much cheaper is it to buy by the dozen"?
### Response:

The dozen rule in North America means there are 12 in a dozen. The number doesn't seem quite as large as it was when I was a kid. When I was a kid, "there were eleven" was an expression people used, even though there was still a dozen eggs in a dozen. If one was selling something, the trick to fool the customer into thinking they weren't getting a great deal was to use the "dozen" to count the 12, but not the 13.

The customer might see a dozen eggs for $2 but they expect to pay 12 x $1, or $12. If asked, the person selling them would say "you can get 12 for $4", not mentioning that it was really 13 for $2. So there's a little extra bang for the buck, even before you break it up and have all those lovely single eggs.

###Response:

It is a tough question to answer. A dictionary is, by definition, a record of the English language. According to the official OED, it is a word, used correctly in a sentence, that is part of the English language. The current edition of the dictionary is 12,000 pages long and has a 30 million word index. It defines more than 640,000 words, not including prefixes, prefixes, and suffixes.

###Response: It is a tough question, but it is actually a bit easier than it seems.

A dictionary doesn't just have definitions. It also contains the history and use of words. All the words of the English language are recorded in dictionaries, even if they are not always listed as being in the English language. When all of these items are recorded, they can be used as a guide to the language.

### Solution:
```bash
#!/bin/bash

read -p 'Please choose the answer and press enter: (1-5)' -n 1 -r ANSWER

case "$ANSWER" in
    1)  Answer=A
    printf "$Answer\n\n"
    ;;
    2)  Answer=B
    printf "$Answer and more\n\n" 
    ;;
    3)  Answer=C
    printf "$Answer  is on its way\n\n"    
    ;;
    4)  Answer=D
    printf "$Answer is the internet\n\n"   
    ;;
    5)  Answer=E
    printf "$Answer loves you\n\n"  
    ;;
esac

exit 0
```
